awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Seismic Isolation of Embedded Foundations Using Periodic Meta-material Barriers to Create Resilient Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
The severity of damage caused by earthquakes over the past decades underscores the need for improvements to reduce the associated threat to America's economy and the safety of its citizens.  Evidence in more recent earthquakes shows that conventional seismic isolation systems are effective in reducing the damage from horizontal components of earthquake shaking.  However, conventional isolation systems are not well suited for protection against the vertical components of earthquake shaking, nor can they be readily used for embedded or underground structures.  To overcome the disadvantages in the conventional seismic isolation systems, we have developed innovative periodic material-based seismic isolators.  Periodic material-based seismic isolators possess distinct frequency band gaps which block, filter, and reflect incoming ground vibrations with frequencies falling between these gaps.  These frequency band gaps can be designed to block ground motions that are harmful to structures.  Previous studies have shown periodic foundations, made of periodic material-based seismic isolators, to be effective in isolating ground motions for structures built on the ground surface.  This project will investigate periodic material-based seismic isolation systems of embedded or underground structures.  The knowledge gained from this research will have broad and far-reaching significance that goes beyond conventional commercial and residential buildings and extends to all types of structures located in seismic zones.  Results from this research can impact the development of seismic design codes on a universal basis.

This project involves the investigation of periodic meta-material barriers-based seismic isolation systems for development of resilient structures.  The periodic meta-material barriers-based seismic isolation system is a complementary system to be applied together with periodic foundations.  Both periodic barriers and periodic foundations are inspired by phononic crystal, which can isolate the seismic waves using the frequency band gap mechanism.  With this mechanism, the incoming seismic waves falling within the frequency band gaps of the properly designed periodic foundations or barriers will be filtered out regardless of the direction of wave propagation.  The periodic foundations, which also act as the foundation of the superstructure, can isolate seismic waves coming from the soil beneath the embedded foundations.  Periodic barriers, on the other hand, will isolate the embedded structures from the incoming lateral seismic waves.  The combination of periodic barriers and periodic foundation will form an isolation envelope for the embedded foundations. This project will study the effectiveness of the combined periodic barriers and the periodic foundation systems through numerical simulation and field studies.  The field studies will examine how seismic waves propagate in soil with and without periodic barriers.  The main objective of this project is to develop periodic barriers that can effectively attenuate incoming seismic waves.  This project will also generate a set of simplified design guidelines for practicing engineers to design periodic barriers that will attenuate seismic shaking.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The severity of damage caused by earthquakes over the past decades underscores the need for improvements to reduce the associated threat to America?s economy and the safety of its citizens. Evidence in recent earthquakes shows that conventional seismic isolation systems are effective in reducing the damage from horizontal components of earthquake shaking. However, conventional isolation systems are not well suited for protection against the vertical components of earthquake shaking, nor can they be readily used for embedded or underground structures. To overcome the disadvantages in the conventional seismic isolation systems, we have developed innovative periodic metamaterial-based seismic isolators. Metamaterial-based seismic isolators possess distinct frequency band gaps which block, filter and reflect incoming ground vibrations with frequencies falling between these gaps. These frequency band gaps can be designed to block ground motions that are harmful to structures.  This project investigated metamaterial-based seismic isolation systems of embedded or underground structures. The knowledge gained from this research has a broad and far-reaching significance that goes beyond conventional commercial and residential buildings and extends to all types of structures located in seismic zones. The metamaterial foundations, which also act as the foundation of the superstructure, can isolate seismic waves coming from the soil beneath the embedded foundations. Metamaterial barriers, on the other hand, isolate the embedded structures from the incoming lateral seismic waves. The combination of metamaterial barriers and metamaterial foundation forms an isolation envelope for the embedded foundations. This project investigated the effectiveness of the combined metamaterial barriers and the metamaterial foundation systems through numerical simulation and field studies. The field studies examined how seismic waves propagate in soil with and without metamaterial barriers.

In this study, a series of finite element simulation and field tests were conducted to assess the combined usage of the metamaterial-based barrier and foundation in a manner to achieve a better wave isolation effect. Scaled models were constructed and tested for both active and passive isolations (see Images 1.) A photograph showing the installation of the periodic barrier is presented in Image 2.  Two hydraulic mobile shakers, named T-Rex and Thumper, available at the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure Equipment Facility at the University of Texas at Austin (NHERI@UTexas) were utilized as vibrational sources in this study. Image 3 shows a photograph of T-Rex used as vibrational source for passive isolation tests where the wave barrier is installed close to the protected region to reduce the vibrations entering the protected region. As shown in Image 3, 3-D geophones and 3-D accelerometers, available at NHERI@UTexas, were used to monitor motions on the building model, soils underneath the building foundation, and ground surface near the periodic barriers.  Effectiveness of the periodic foundation and the periodic barriers were determined based on the motions recorded from these 3-D geophones and accelerometers. The finite element simulation and field test results show that the filtering capability of the metamaterial barrier and foundation is complementary to each other, and the combined usage of the metamaterial barrier and the metamaterial foundation is beneficial to mitigating the vibration of the protected superstructure (see Image 4).

The extent of the real-life impact of the proposed work is commensurate with the fact that the seismic performance of engineering structures of all types and sizes can be enhanced by this innovative and more efficient system of isolation. The knowledge gained from this research has broad and far-reaching significance that goes beyond conventional commercial and residential buildings and extends to all types of structures located in seismic zones. Results from this research also provide design guidelines for practicing engineers. Undergraduate and graduate students gained in-depth knowledge of innovative metamaterial materials and structures by direct participation in research and new course modules developed through this project.
